text: Henry Stewart or Stuart, Duke of Albany (7 December 1546 – 10 February 1567), styled Lord Darnley before 1565, was king consort of Scotland from 1565 to his murder at Kirk o' Field. Usually called Lord Darnley, he was the father of James VI and I. Darnley was the second son of Matthew Stewart, 4th Earl of Lennox, and his wife, Lady Margaret Douglas. He was their oldest surviving son. Darnley's maternal grandparents were Archibald Douglas, 6th Earl of Angus, and Margaret Tudor, widow of James IV of Scotland. It is commonly believed that Darnley was born on 7 December, but that is disputed. He was a first cousin and the second husband of Mary, Queen of Scots, and was the father of her son James VI of Scotland, who succeeded Elizabeth I of England as James I of England.Elaine Finnie Greig, 'Stewart, Henry, duke of Albany [Lord Darnley] (1545/6–1567)', Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, Jan 2008 accessed 4 March 2012 Darnley was found dead outdoors while he was dressed for bed after an explosion near his bedroom. Many people thought that Mary had arranged his murder. == References == Category:Kings and Queens consort of Scotland Category:1545 births Category:1567 deaths Category:Assassinated people
title: Henry Stuart, Lord Darnley
